ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth was so so great. She always explained things really well and had alternate ways to explain when I was having trouble understanding.

Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Liz was really kind and helpful. She was always willing to help answer questions and explain topics. She worked hard to help us understand things and she was a kind exam proctor. I loved her as my T.A.
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth Creech
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Great TA!
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth was typically who helped me during office hours. She was always really patient and helpful.
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Creech, Elizabeth
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth Creech

Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth was super helpful and fun to be around. She had a great grasp of the material and knew how to explain difficult content in a way that was straight-forward and uncomplicated.
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  She was amazing! So helpful

Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Creech was a great TF, very attentive, answered questions and emails promptly, and was really effective in communicating concepts when they needed more explanation.
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth Creech
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth Creek
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth Creech
Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Steph was really nice!

Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Stephanie was truly an ally. She was upfront about what she knew and didn't know, and was happy to be a resource and "learn along" with material she had forgotten. Very patient and made me feel welcome as a less science-based student.
Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Also good TA!
Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Ratte, Stephanie
Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Stephanie Ratte
Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Steph is a great person and TA. She is extremely bright and was always willing to help with difficult material.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Creech used to be a middle school science teacher and it shows. She is really good at helping explain concepts to students (esp. chemistry). Very nice and makes you feel good about physical sciences.

Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  She has an amazing technique for teaching sciences, specially with those who are really starters. She is committed and really worry for you to learn. Very good knowledge of the topics. Elizabeth was incredible!!
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth is the best!! She was also very accessible and helpful, turning the difficult material into common language

Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  I didn't rely much on the TAs, just a bit when we were doing the problem sets in class. In general I feel that Shimi explains the materials better, but the TAs were certainly helpful on several occasions, like when Elizabeth explains to us what is organic vs. inorganic.

Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth Creech was always accessible during our problem set work time in class and during office hours. She explained topics very clearly and was always happy to help.
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Strengths - communication, ability to explain complex principles in simple terms, accessibility
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth was very helpful in answering questions and quick to respond to email inquiries.

Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth was very helpful and wanted students to fully grasp the material. She was patient, listened carefully to our questions, and responded in a thorough and creative manner. The only weakness is not of Elizabeth but the class. Due to the fact that it covers so much material, there was more information than any individual TA could know. If she didn't know the answer, she was honest and followed up after discussing the question with the professor.
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Great TF! Very approachable, familiar with course material, articulate, incredible facilitator in group discussions, always willing to help.
Instructor: Elizabeth Cheryl Creech  Elizabeth was very patient and able to break down material into digestible chunks. Her experience has a middle school educator served here well as a TA.
Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Strengths: -very approachable -willing to go at a slow pace in one-on-one setting Weaknesses: n/a
Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Steph is so nice and knowledgeable. Both TAs were very nice which made it really easy to ask them for help.

Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  I didn't rely much on the TAs, just a bit when we were doing the problem sets in class. In general I feel that Shimi explains the materials better, but the TAs were certainly helpful on several occasions.
Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Stephanie Ratte was very helpful during our problem set work times and office hours. She was very patient with even the most basic questions.
Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  I did not interact with Stephanie often but she was always polite and helpful in explaining concepts relevant to the coursework.

Instructor: Stephanie Mariko Ratte  Steph was patient and helpful TA. She was quick to answer questions on the homework and would even check in outside of the class to make sure that we were understanding the material.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Shimi was fantastic. He gives so much of his time to students, totally understands their concerns (from a personal and a technical level), and is incredibly supportive!
Shimi was the best part about this course (but the material was cool, too).
Shimi is really interested in making sure that all of his students have a positive learning experience, and being in his class is a complete delight.

To be honest, I was completely dreading this class. I have very little formal training in science and was unsure of how I would fare even in an introductory course. It was a complete surprise to me that by the end of this semester, this course ended up as my favorite. To say I learned a lot in this class would be an understatement - I am a completely different student now than I was when I first walked through the door. It was by no means an easy course (in fact, I struggled quite a bit) but it was incredibly rewarding.
Incredible course. Shimi is a dedicated and passionate instructor that everyone at FES should work with at some point in their education here!

Shimi was really diligent about going through concepts that we seemed to have trouble with and that was much appreciated. He was also so incredibly generous with his time and energy - so accessible. He does a wonderful job of being careful but efficient with the massive amount of learning material. Shimi is the best!

Questions 13: Shimi always made a strong effort to explain difficult concepts to students and was readily available after class and outside of class. Overall, I was very pleased with the split course format and Shimi altered individual class sessions to explain material in online lectures depending on students' score on out-of-class quizzes.

Shimi is hands down the best science teacher that I have ever had. He is excellent. His concern for the students is evident from the first day. He carefully reviews the material and is able to explain these complex concepts in a number of different methods. He is thoughtful, integrating student questions into the homework sets so that we can learn more about the issues that interest us. I cannot recommend him enough.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Shimi is a really good teacher and it seems like he sincerely wants everyone to do well. I liked the flipped course format.
Shimi and the TAs. The water section was most interesting to me.

Shimi was very approachable and made himself easily accessible for questions or extra help. He hosted so many review sessions before the exam and helped his students genuinely understand the material. The class is taught flipped which is a great arrangement because it lets people learn at their own pace. The quizzes every week were also helpful for him to gauge how people were doing with the material which he then went over in class later.
Having Shimi as the professor! Also the fact that it was flipped, and getting to learn about climate science. You'd think FES would have more courses on climate change but I think this is about it.
The course is well structured, the content is very useful for professional purposes. Inspire you to look up for more information about earth sciences.
Shimi's great!
While this course was alot of work, I think it afforded students every opportunity to succeed and seek out extra help if needed. It also covered a great deal of material in one semester.
A VERY good foundation of physical sciences. It's information that we should all know as we work in the environmental field!
This was a very good introductory course. Covers a lot of material and it is made as simple as possible and it is easy to understand.

Shimi is an amazing teacher. He presents complicated material in clear and concise ways. He kept the course simultaneously very challenging and very manageable at the same time. The flipped classroom provided plenty of opportunity for clarification both from Shimi, from the TAs and from fellow students.

Shimi is the best professor I had all semester, hands down. I know my skill set and learning style is so different from his, but he always made me feel at ease and comfortable in asking questions - regardless of how elementary they might be. In addition to the instruction, the clear structure of the course - with video lectures and class notes available - made the large amount of material covered manageable.
The problem sets and quizzes were demanding but really important to my learning. Shimi's office hours and reviews sessions were critical for clarification of concepts.

Shimi's ability to cover a vast amount of information in a coherent way in such a short amount of time made this course worth taking. The intermittent environmental examples that tied the concepts together really helped bring the more conceptual material into a 'real world' focus.

The flipped course material, online quizzes, and problem sets made it convenient for students to review material, improve their understanding of the material, and prepare for exams. Shimi is very thorough in explaining the material and strives for all students to understand difficult concepts.
This course provides vital information for anyone hoping to pursue a career in the environmental sector
Professor Anisfield. He is a remarkable professor.
-Shimi was very responsive to student questions and clearly cares about his students. The teaching assistants were excellent.

1. Video lectures. Able to pause and look up unfamiliar concepts and interesting points. 2. Applicable assignment activities teach us how the science is actually done in real world. For example, I really enjoyed using USGS and NOAA databases to evaluate the state of drought in Connecticut, and the variability of sea level rise across North America. These activities deepen our understanding of course materials.

Shimi is a phenomenal instructor. He is so knowledgeable and very skilled at convey complex information to an audience that may not have much experience in this field. It is obvious that he as spent a great deal of time refining the course, and his commitment to being a good teacher is noted and admirable. The flipped structure works very well in this course.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I wish that things had moved a little slower. We covered so much that it had to be pretty fast, but sometimes spending more time would have really helped me understand the material better.
Quizzes sometimes seemed to be quite harder than the material learned in the video lectures.

On weeks where we have an exam, we would also have quizzes for new material which was overwhelming and not conducive to learning. The review sessions could have been a part of class as well which would have been easier for students.

The course covers a LOT of material. I personally would have liked more of a refresher on chemistry, but there just didn't seem to be time. I also never felt like I fully understood everything we had to know about rocks.
Perhaps some experiments or lab work would help to understand in a practical way some concepts covered.
there's a steep learning curve in this class with the flipped-class style, but otherwise everything is great

We had to prepare for unit exams (and the final) while we were still learning new material fo the next unit. It was ALOT of work outside of class and I think there was a certain level of knowledge assumed for students coming in.

I didn't get much out of the problem sets where we were just plugging numbers into formulas. Maybe instead of a short problem set per class it will be better to have a longer one per week that helps us delve deeper into the topic. At times it was also unclear why we were learning certain facts. It will be great to have more examples in class or readings of short articles in problem sets to help us better understand the significance of the concepts. I'd also like to see more connections between the three modules that we studied (Water, Air, Climate). For example at the end of the course one classmate explained to us the Nitrogen cycle and it was so great to connect the dots between all the pieces we have learned regarding the N cycle.
Sometimes the pace of the in-class lectures and clicker questions were too fast to follow.
The two-test final was...tough.

My only complaint is that sometimes questions of the exams were not indicative of what was stressed in class. Like it would be a very specific memorization question versus a more systems-thinking question. But those were few and far between.
The course covers a wide amount of material. I am not sure that there is a solution to this challenge as all of the material is important.

-The powerpoints for this course need a lot of improvement. I suggest that a teaching assistant be hired to revise the format/content of the powerpoints. -It was assumed that students already understood many concepts that were covered, which resulted in a fast-paced course that left some students behind. I know that some of the international students in class struggled a lot with this. -This is a flipped course, so I expected most of class time to be spent on problem sets. However, at least half of each class was a lecture during which we reviewed material from the recorded lectures and in which new information was introduced. Thus, students had limited time to work on their problem sets in class and ended up having to finish their problem sets outside of class (which often required taking time to go to office hours and get help from the TAs) and watch all recorded lectures for the next class. If the powerpoints and recorded lectures were clearer, I don't think it would be necessary to spend so much time in class going over the materials, and the course would function more efficiently.

Linkage among the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and lithosphere could be strengthened. For example, biogeochemical cycling of C and N span across the 3 systems. By the time we studied global N budget and fluxes in section 4.5, anthropocentric perturbations to the N cycle (e.g. aquatic eutrophication) that were covered earlier in the semester in the water quality lectures seemed a little disconnected.
The last section, atmosphere, was a bit rushed, but otherwise this class was exceptional. Hands down my favorite class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Shimi made himself very available to students, as did the teaching fellows. I did not take advantage of office hours regularly (only before exams), but there was ample time to ask Shimi and the TFs questions during class.
The wrap-up readings and in-class discussion at the end of each module were great! I would not cut any of them, I think the back-to-back exams at the end were ok.

The flipped classroom was a bit of an adjustment, but I think it worked well to have remedial lectures and time to work on problem sets be the 'class' time, with the video lectures available to view whenever

The case studies at the end of each section could be improved. Often times only the presenters were able to grasp the reading materials, while the rest simply sat back and passively listen. It would help to add quizzes similar to regular sections, so that we can all absorb the take-home message of assigned papers/video interviews.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I don't have a science background, but this survey makes me feel much better prepared to take a wide variety of classes in the natural sciences, especially water.

I don't have any background in sciences, so this course was really helpful and inspiring for understanding the science behind environmental development initiatives. I starting with almost zero knowledge on earth sciences, but now I know more and will keep up educating myself on this.
This provides fundamental knowledge for environmental science.

This course gave a broad range of scientific background knowledge so that you can speak intelligently about the topics that you won't necessarily be researching but will be interacting with on a regular basis.

I didn't have a strong science background so this class was super helpful in filling in my knowledge gaps. I am not sure I will take more natural science classes at FES but this class provided basic science knowledge that all environmental professionals should know.
For someone like me, working on environmental policy, it is very important to have a good and, at least, basic understanding of the physical sciences behind environmental phenomenon.
This really should be a required course for any students like myself who do not have a hard science background. I know I will be a better policy adviser in the future having taken this course.

Amazing course for my scientific foundation before moving forward in other course. I've learned a lot of these concepts in undergrad but not as well and not within the env. management context, so this course was very valuable to me.
I did not take many courses in the sciences in undergrad, so this class was necessary in order to fully understand the underlying concepts behind work in many of my other F&ES classes

Coming from a social science background, I wanted to better understand climate science for environmental policy analysis purposes. The course helped strengthen my understanding of these scientific concepts.
Provides a solid environmental science foundation

As an MEM student with little hard science background, this course was very helpful. The knowledge I gained will not only help me in my career but it is already popping up in my day-to-day conversations.

Even though I came from a science background (marine science and biology), by general knowledge of hydrology, geomorphology, soil science, and atmospheric chemistry was very limited. After taking this course, I am now able to understand primary literature in these fields, which is necessary for my MESc thesis work.
I am focused on water resource management. This course provides a strong foundation for tackling water issues.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: My background is social science, and I wanted to learn more about the natural/hard science side.
Prep for higher level courses.
I wanted to learn about climate change and climate science. Success!
lack of knowledge in the subject area
I don't have a strong science background and I thought it would be useful. Plus, I heard Shimi was the best teacher at FES (which is true).
as a complement from the natural sciences perspective for my work on policy/social sciences
I took this course because I felt that I needed more of a solid foundation in physical science.

Coming from a social science background, I wanted to better understand climate science for environmental policy analysis purposes. The course helped strengthen my understanding of these scientific concepts. I also took this course as a prerequisite for Shimi's Water Resource Management course.
To gain a deeper understanding of earth sciences.
To became scientifically literate in hydrology and soil science, so that I can catch up with the knowledge gap for my MESc thesis work.
It is a pre-requisite for many courses I hope to take, and I wanted a refresher on physical sciences.
Honestly, because I didn't place out of it. I'm glad I did, it was a good course overall. But had I been able to place out of it, I would not have taken it.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes.
Yes. I had wanted to learn about climate science and now I feel as though I have a good grasp of the general issues.
Yes!
yeah! i intended to learn more about geology and earth science and that's what i did.

It went above and beyond. Shimi did a great job teaching and making sure students really understood the material. The class was alot of work but probably one of the most useful classes in all of my years in school.

YES! The class was extremely well-organized. The videos and readings were very informative. Shimi's explanation in class was engaging and clear. Shimi is also very accessible. I wish I had more time to go to his office hours to get even more out of the course!
the amount of material and topics covered in class is so broad and it is made so simple and easy to understand that the class exceeded my expectations.

Yes. This course covers a lot of information in a short period of time, but what you get out of it really reflects what you put in. If you put in the time with the material, you will come out with a strong foundational understanding of the subject matter.
Above and beyond my expectations.
Yes
Yes, I gained a lot from taking the course. I feel more prepared to discuss and work with scientific concepts in hydrology, physics, biology, and chemistry.
Yes
It exceeded my expectations.
-Yes
Yes. Fully!
Yes! Exceeded them really.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was informal group work (working on problem sets with other students). It was a very helpful part of the class, and I appreciated having the flipped course structure so we could do that.
We worked on problem sets in groups, but you could do so individually. It was a great way to get to know classmates.
Advantages of learning from one another doing problem sets.
Very advantageous to work together on problem sets in class instead of struggling alone at home. Major benefit to the flipped class structure!

The course is set up to encourage students to work together in small groups to complete homework sets. These homework groups were very helpful as we could take out the questions together and learn from each other.
See my response to Question 19.
It was great to talk through complex topics with classmates. Very helpful.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Stay on top of work. Take notes while you are watching the videos; be an active learner. Take advantage of TA and evening help sessions.

Shimi is just wonderful. He really cares about his students and goes out of his way to be available if you ever need help on anything. There is a lot of material to cover in this course, but Shimi makes it fun. I LOVED that the course was flipped--that really helped my understanding and allowed for more time to ask questions of Shimi while working on the problem sets in class. Personally, I think this course should be required for anyone who is interested in climate change in any way. The information you learn is very important no matter where you go on to in the environmental field.
Be ready to invest a lot of time in the course, but totally worth. NASA videos are also useful for those visual learners.
be patient with yourself with the flipped classroom. if you're not familiar with this type of learning, there's a steep learning curve, but you'll get the hang of it eventually.

Although you may not be going into the hard sciences you should still have an idea of whats going on in the world. This course gives that overview and Shimi is the most hard-working and responsive professor I've had here.
Be prepared for alot of time spent outside of class in order to grasp the materials. Go to office hours often!

Take it if you feel you need to improve your science foundation! The workload is heavier than a normal course but it is broken down into small chunks so it is manageable. When you study for a module exam, take good review notes/ make flash cards so that when the final exam comes around you can review everything quickly. This is the best class I took this semester and I would highly recommend it to other students.

If you do not have a background in physical science, you should take this course. It covers topics that any personal with an environmental management degree should be well-versed in, no matter what your specialization is. Be prepared for a lot of work. If you don't put in the time, you won't get anything out of the course. If you do, you will benefit greatly. I highly recommend this course.
Take it. You will be better off because of it.
Do it! Before taking it I was unsure of how the specifics of the material covered would fit in to my overall course of study, but it ended up being very relevant, plus Shimi is an excellent educator.

I would recommend that any students who did not take scientific courses throughout their undergraduate studies take the course. I believe that understanding the science behind climate change is essential to crafting solutions to the wicked problems we face in the field. Shimi works really hard to ensure that all students learn the material and understand the concepts covered in the course. I highly recommend this course to incoming students, especially those without a strong scientific background.
Take it. It is a great course and Shimi is an excellent professor.
-Be prepared for a fast-paced course that is very quantitative. -Print out every powerpoint and take detailed lecture notes.
This course covers a broad range of topics. Focus on the field you are most interested in and go beyond the books.
Just take it. You won't regret it.
Be aware of the flipped nature of the course. The majority of learning is in video lecture and quizzes taken out of class time. If this isn't for you, this course might not be right for you.
